top_comment.text:
I wouldn't get everything from Daiso though, such as cosmetics.. On 
Japanese channels 100y make up tutorials are pretty hilarious though, but 
soaps, etc. contacting with skin could be irritating. Never buy scissors, 
nail clippers, etc. they'll all fall apart, towels aren't comfy either etc. 
A lot of stuff you can get from Muji with 100-200y more pricey, but winner 
quality. Wouldn't trust on bento boxes either. Instead: all wrapping, gift, 
craft materials, daily necessities from q-tips to cleaning equipment, all 
seasonal and party products, all together everything you can't think of 
getting quick and cheap anywhere else in the city. For Japanese learners, 
there's lots of those empty notebooks for 50y where you can practise kanji 
writing.﻿

comments.author: babydoll buck

top_comment.text:
I love when you mentioned that the pink striped bag looks like a Victoria 
Secret bag and Jun was all, "Hotoni?" haha. I would like to request another 
video on language. Let me clarify, I've noticed in Japan there are sounds 
that have a meaning. I noticed you and Jun using them throughout the video. 
And I haven't seen one yet. Arigato﻿
top_comment.author: Claire De Luna

comments.text:
No problem. I think I should explain what I mean by sounds. I hear things 
like, "Aa, mm, or oh..." And they get translated into English on animes and 
what have you, but it's interesting to me, that simple sounds carry actual 
meaning. I noticed it in your vids when you converse with one another, you 
both do it, and I hear it in shows and what have you. I've never seen a vid 
that actually explains these sounds. If anyone has, I'd be interested in 
seeing it.
comments.author: Claire De Luna

comments.text:
omg thank you because I hear that word literally everywhere and I could 
never find what it meant in google
comments.author: Ash V

comments.text:
"honto ni" means "truly", "actually", "really"

"ni" doesn't have meaning in or of itself, but in this case it changes a 
noun into an adverbial interjection/intensifier.

I misspelled it, in my moment of amusement, but if I'm wrong someone please 
correct me.
comments.author: Claire De Luna

comments.text: do you know what hotoni means?

went to Japan and there is one time I took photo of their souvenir.. The 
shop owner's wife saw and started shouting at me many times "deleto!!!' 
then came his husband shouting the same thing and point at my phone, he

shop shouting "OUTO!"..

top_comment.text: whats bento?﻿
top_comment.author: Neji Hyuga

comments.text: i think it's a japenese lunch box.
comments.author: victoria rose

comments.text:
A bento is a boxed meal. (Bento box = Lunch box) Some mothers are so into 
making appetizing looking bento's, they will wake up two hours before their 
kids, just so they can create these elaborate, pretty looking lunches. 
(Seriously, you should google it, they are amazing.) It can be a variety of 
different dishes with rice, vegetables and meat, but it can also just be a 
sandwich. 

(The thing Arturo is talking about is called 'Onigiri' which is a stuffed 
rice ball.)
comments.author: keniakittykat
